uk.ac.aber.dcs.odj.concordance
Class Concordance

java.lang.Object
  java.util.Dictionary<K,V>
      java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,LittleLinkedList<WordEntry>>
          uk.ac.aber.dcs.odj.concordance.Concordance
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Map<java.lang.String,LittleLinkedList<WordEntry>>
public class Concordance
extends java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,LittleLinkedList<WordEntry>>

A class based on Hashtable, which when supplied with a filename and an array of index words (as Strings), can generate a Concordance of the text - the number of times a word appears in the text is counted, along with its line numbers and contexts (the sentence/sentence fragment in which the word was found.

Author:
Owain Jones
See Also:

Constructor Detail

Concordance

public Concordance()
Creates an empty Concordance (Hashtable) object with no keys or values.

Concordance

public Concordance(java.lang.String file,
                   java.lang.String[] index)
            throws java.io.IOException

Creates a new Concordance and populates the underlying Hashtable keys with the array of words (Strings) given in the index argument.

The Hashtable keys (the index) are the words you want the Concordance to scan for in the document.

Parameters:
file - The document (Absolute file path) for the Concordance to scan
index - The String[] array to generate the Hashtable keys from
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if file couldn't be loaded for some reason.

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if file couldn't be loaded for some reason.

generateIndex

public void generateIndex(java.lang.String[] index)
For every word in the index, create a respective key in the Concordance's underlying Hashtable. This key is associated with an empty LittleLinkedList. (The LittleLinkedList is the key's value)

isPunctuation

public static boolean isPunctuation(char c)
Check if a character is a punctuation symbol: full stops (.), periods (,), exclamation marks, question marks, [semi]colons, and the different forms of brackets are all counted as punctuation.

Parameters:
c - char to check
Returns:
true or false

isWord

public static boolean isWord(java.lang.String s)
Check if a string is a word, grammatically: if the string consists of ONLY alphanumeric characters, plus apostrophes (') and hyphens (-), it is a word. If any other characters are found (such as whitespace), it isn't a word.

Parameters:
s - The String to check
Returns:
true if string is word, false if not

scan

public void scan()
          throws java.io.IOException

Scan through the text file defined in the Concordance constructor or setFile, character by character. Looks for words which are listed in the concordance's index (using Hashtable.containsKey(word)) and adds the references (line number and context) as WordEntry objects to that word's respective LittleLinkedList.

The contexts for every WordEntry are generated based on sentence fragment boundaries - the algorithm assumes that, whenever a punctuation character is found, it's seperating two pieces of text, so contexts are the character range from one piece of punctuation (e.g. a full stop) to the next (e.g. a comma or a full-stop).

Example:
"That's not the most grandiose of natural language processing", said Owain - if we were looking for 'grandiose' or 'processing', their contexts would both be the part within the speech marks.

scan() doesn't return anything, because the internal state of this Concordance (a Hashtable after all) is altered by the method. Once scan() has returned, you can access the elements as you would a normal Hashtable.

Example:
Concordance.scan(); Concordance.get("word").size(); // get the number of references to this word found after running a scan()

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if something happens to the document file (e.g. it's modified whilst we're reading it)
